header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: Article on World Peace Part 11

central_thesis: True world peace and societal construction can only be achieved by abandoning the self-serving principle of 'Truth' (mine is mine and yours is yours) which inevitably leads to destruction, and instead embracing the altruistic principle of 'Mercy' (giving for the sake of others). This is necessitated by humanity's current state of global interdependence, where the welfare of any individual or nation is intrinsically tied to the welfare of the entire world, making a global shift in ethical operating principles imperative.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the core topics to be discussed: the nature of peacemakers, the dichotomy of 'Truth is Destruction; Mercy is Construction', and the foundational concept that 'The Entire World is one community & One Society'.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Destructive Nature of Truth and the Constructive Power of Mercy
structure_content.summary: This part elaborates on the concept that 'Truth' as a principle ('mine is mine and yours is yours') inherently leads to destruction and conflict, often championed by aggressive 'People of Destruction' who ironically seek peace through their self-interested views. Conversely, 'Mercy' is presented as the principle of construction, embodied by 'People of Construction' who are willing to give and sacrifice for others, though often perceived as weak. The text asserts that lasting peace cannot be established by those who operate from the destructive principle of Truth.

structure_content.chapter_title: The World as One Community and Society (Part 1)
structure_content.summary: The author argues that modern society has evolved to a point where the entire world functions as a single, interconnected community. Individual well-being and vitality are now derived from the global population, thereby obligating each individual to serve and care for the entire world. This concept highlights the total subservience of the individual to the global community, akin to a cog in a machine, where individual good is inseparable from the collective good.

structure_content.chapter_title: The World as One Community and Society (Part 2)
structure_content.summary: This section traces the historical progression of human interconnectedness, from families to towns, then to countries, demonstrating how the scope of individual reliance and obligation has expanded. It concludes that in the current era, where all countries contribute to an individual's happiness and needs, individual subservience must extend to the whole world. Therefore, achieving peace and happiness in one country while neglecting the rest of the world is deemed inconceivable.

structure_content.chapter_title: Global Interdependence and the Role of Action
structure_content.summary: This final part reinforces the idea that all countries are now mutually dependent for life's necessities. Consequently, the focus must shift from securing peace for a single nation to securing peace for the entire world. It emphasizes that the welfare of any individual is directly dependent on the welfare of all individuals globally. The text concludes that while these principles may be known, full assimilation requires direct 'actions' that will 'teach humanity and push it forward'.

key_concepts.definition: A principle based on strict self-interest and 'mine is mine and yours is yours,' leading to aggressive promotion of individual or national views, which ultimately results in conflict and societal breakdown.
A principle based on altruism, self-sacrifice, and a willingness to give for the sake of others, which is the foundation for building and sustaining peace and societal well-being.

Individuals, often peace advocates, who paradoxically cause destruction by operating from the principle of 'Truth,' aggressively pushing their self-interested views, risking lives for what they deem right.
Individuals who seek 'Mercy' and righteousness, willing to give up their own interests for others to save the world, often perceived as 'cowards' but are the true agents of construction and peace.

key_concepts.term: The Entire World is one community & One Society
key_concepts.definition: The core sociological and ethical assertion that humanity has reached a state of complete global interdependence, where the well-being and vitality of any single individual or nation are inextricably linked to the well-being of the whole world.

The obligation of an individual to serve the broader community (now the entire world) because their own life and needs are derived from that community, thus aligning individual good with collective good.

The philosophical idea that intellectual assimilation of global unity and the necessity of Mercy will not come merely through theory, but through concrete, real-world actions that embody these principles, thereby leading humanity forward to true understanding.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is primarily one of ethical and philosophical transformation, rather than ritual magic. It advocates for a fundamental shift in consciousness from prioritizing self-interest ('Truth') to prioritizing altruism and communal well-being ('Mercy'). This shift is to be enacted through real-world 'actions' which are believed to be the primary 'teachers' of humanity, leading to a deeper understanding and assimilation of the global-as-one-community concept. The 'operative' side involves consciously choosing to serve the entire world and to act with Mercy, recognizing that one's own welfare is inextricably linked to the welfare of all.

relevant_quotes.text: Truth is Destruction; Mercy is Construction

The subjects, who are the peace makers of our generation and of every other generation, who have the power in their hand to make Peace in the world, are forever made from that human stuff which we call People of Destruction.
This is because they seek Truth, that is, they want the world to run by the principle 'mine is mine is mine and yours is yours.'
In other words: seeking for Truth is the same as the destruction of the world. And seeking Mercy is the same as the construction of the world.
Because, in reality, we have reached such a level that the whole world is considered as only one community and one society.
That is to say, since every individual in society derives his vitality and every need from the people of the entire world, he is thereby obliged to serve the entire world and to care for it.

And therefore, the possibility that one could peacefully create good and happy procedures in one country, while neglecting to do so in all the countries of the world, and vice versa, is inconceivable.
Because the welfare and calamity of each and every individual in the world are dependent on, and limited by, the degree of the welfare to individuals all over the world.
This is why actions alone will teach humanity and push it forward.

critical_analysis.relevance: This article, rooted in the Kabbalistic teachings of Rav Ashlag, offers a profound ethical and philosophical framework for understanding the mechanisms of peace and conflict. Its central thesis — that global interdependence necessitates a shift from self-interest ('Truth') to altruism ('Mercy') for true construction — is exceptionally relevant in today's interconnected world grappling with global challenges such as climate change, economic inequality, and geopolitical tensions. It critiques conventional approaches to peace that often fail by focusing on national self-interest, aligning instead with a holistic, spiritual perspective on human responsibility. The emphasis on 'actions' driving understanding provides a practical, albeit challenging, call to transformation.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those interested in the social and ethical dimensions of Rav Ashlag's work. It also appeals to individuals engaged in peace studies, social philosophy, ethics, and interfaith dialogue who seek a spiritual, non-materialistic perspective on global challenges and the path to world peace. Those interested in the underlying spiritual mechanics of societal harmony and disharmony would find this text valuable.
